linkTarget.anchoringText: In late 1986, the Central Gas Facility (CGF) began operation, enabling the first field scale EOR project, Prudhoe Bay Miscible Gas Project (PBMGP), to start in early 1987. Since then, the PBMGP has expanded to more than 170 injection patterns in the main field of Prudhoe Bay. Miscible gas injection was expanded to Prudhoe Bay Eileen West End (EWE) in 2002 and to the satellite fields in 2003. Figure 1 provides a layout of the oil fields on the North Slope of Alaska and Table 1 is a summary of the current MI EOR projects across the GPB fields.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Area map of Alaska North Slope

formatted-caption.caption-text: Area map of Alaska North Slope

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 2 illustrates the application of this technique using an in-house software tool called Foretell. On the left semi-log plot, oil, water, gas and liquid rates are presented against time. There are two oil trends:(1) actual, historical oil rates and (2) oil rate predicted from a waterflood-only [1]Type Curve[1] model which is generated by reservoir simulation models. On the right plot, the log of WOR is plotted against cumulative oil production.

The dynamic production allocation factor changes monthly as a function of the MI injection rates of the offset injectors. The MI rates which are relevant in this calculation are not current rates, but rather those from a prior month, determined by the transit time of MI from injector to producer. Figure 3 illustrates the concept of injection and production allocations.
MI patterns are often ranked in terms of MI utilization as shown in Figure 4. However, ranking based on MI utilization alone does not consider pattern maturity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Ranking of a subset of PBMGP patterns

formatted-caption.caption-text: Ranking of a subset of PBMGP patterns

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5 shows the match between COBRA prediction and field performance of the active patterns in PBMGP. While the performance of individual patterns are scattered above and below the COBRA prediction, the field average performance matches well with the prediction.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Match between PBMGP COBRA prediction and field performance

formatted-caption.caption-text: Match between PBMGP COBRA prediction and field performance

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 6 shows an example output of the historical MI injection and EOR oil production predicted by the PBMGP COBRA model. The cumulative gross MI utilization to date is approximately 10 mscf per stock tank barel of EOR oil produced. Prediction of future MI rate and performance can be very different depending on field development scenarios, such as development of new EOR projects and major gas sales at Prudhoe Bay.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Historical PBMGP MI injection rate and predicted EOR oil production rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Historical PBMGP MI injection rate and predicted EOR oil production rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7 illustrates how MI is allocated to each project. Predicted net MI utilization values are plotted against MI supply to each project. The graph shows that as MI supply rate increases to a certain project, the MI utilization increases because MI is injected into decreasingly efficient patterns. A cut-off value of net MI utilization is determined based on the total amount of MI supply at GPB.
